body.p: Whether you are just beginning with Smalltalk, or want to tackle some advanced development strategies, the following resources can be extremely useful.

section.title: Smalltalk Books
section.p:
There are many Smalltalk books available, and the following are a few of them:
Brauer, Johannes. Programming Smalltalk - Object-Orientation from the Beginning: An Introduction to the Principles of Programming. Springer Vieweg, 2015.
Valloud, Andrés. Fundamentals of Smalltalk Programming Technique. Spotlight, 2009.
Beck, Kent. Smalltalk Best Practice Patterns. Prentice-Hall, 1997.
Having learned how to write Smalltalk, reading this slim book is one of the best ways to learn how to write good Smalltalk.
Alpert, Sherman R, Kyle Brown, and Bobby Woolf. The Design Patterns Smalltalk Companion. Addison-Wesley, 1998.
Parallels the classical "Gang of Four" book on design patterns but focuses on Smalltalk.

There are also several recent books about:
Pharo (Squeak), a very popular dialect of Smalltalk.
The Seaside web framework.
and there are books about Dolphin Smalltalk and IBM's VisualAge Smalltalk.

Beyond this Introduction to Smalltalk, and the other introductory and tutorial materials supplied in the ∏ release, there are many standard works explaining the Smalltalk language, including:
Lewis, Simon. The Art and Science of Smalltalk. Prentice Hall, 1995.
A popular slim book written around ∏.
Goldberg, A, and D Robson. Smalltalk-80 : The Language and Its Implementation. Addison-Wesley, 1989.
The famous "blue book" containing, among other things, a detailed specification of the original Smalltalk run-time system written in Smalltalk.
Winston, Patrick H. On to Smalltalk. Addison-Wesley, 1999.
Slim and readable.
Klimas, Edward J, David A. Thomas, and Suzanne Skublics. Smalltalk with Style. Prentice Hall, 1996.
A list of commented style guidelines written by leading Smalltalk experts.
Tomek, Ivan. The Joy of Smalltalk. Acadia University, 1996. plato.acadiau.ca/courses/comp/tomek/jos.htm. Accessed 22 May 2017.
My own approximately 700-page unpublished text dedicated to ∏ 3.

section.title: Smalltalk Organisations
section.p:
Several professional organisations exist to promote Smalltalk, and hold annual conferences:
The European Smalltalk User Group manages the ESUG conference.
The Smalltalk Industry Council manages the Smalltalk Industry conference.
The Fundacion Argentina de Smalltalk manages the Smalltalks conference.

section.title: Smalltalk Web Sites
section.p: There are many web sites and blogs devoted to Smalltalk; the following is a small selection:
Cincom Smalltalk: the official vendor site for ∏.
Planet Smalltalk aggregates Smalltalk information appearing on the web.

section.title: Smalltalk Newsgroups
section.p: The newsgroup comp.lang.smalltalk is devoted to Smalltalk in general. There are also many more specific fora, including the vwnc@cs.uiuc.edu newsgroup specifically for users of ∏.

section.title: Extreme Programming (XP)
section.p:
The following are some books about XP, a development process favored by many Smalltalk programmers:
Beck, Kent, and Cynthia Andres. Extreme Programming Explained: Second Edition, Embrace Change. Addison-Wesley, 2015.
Kent Beck is co-inventor of design patterns, the testing framework, and Extreme Programming.
Jeffries, Ronald E, Ann Anderson, and Chet Hendrickson. Extreme Programming Installed. Addison-Wesley, 2009.
Wake, William C. Extreme Programming Explored. Boston: Addison Wesley, 2002.
